data.title: Rize (2005)
data.meta_description: A documentary film that highlights two street derived dance styles, Clowning and Krumping, that came out of the low income neighborhoods of L.A.. Director David LaChapelle interviews each dance crew about how their unique dances evolved. A new and positive activity away from the drugs, guns, and gangs that ruled their neighborhood. A raw film about a growing sub-culture movements in America.
data.text:
LaChapelle gets incredible access and there are some stunning images here, but he doesn't feel like the kind of filmmaker who can organize all this incredible footage into a particularly coherent picture of this dance culture at a specific moment of time.

Lucky for him, what he's chronicling is rich enough that it overcomes his weaknesses. There are some incredible people profiled here and it's a thrill to see their art presented so beautifully. Absolutely teared up and then rewound the footage of Lil C dancing on the beach at sunset. Cinema. I do wish LaChappelle dug into his and some of his other subjects' lives more rather than making this montage of an experience. It works intermittently like at…

the fact time & time again this film makes me cry. since i caught the initial premiere w my mom & brother, i have LOVED rize since. this is my first time watching it in awhile and i most admire the fact my heavy feelings remain. my brother & i shared our first copy of the dvd and literally watched this EVERYDAY. mostly watching for the thrill of it and then becoming versions of krumpers ourselves. i adored the clowns but boy were they always carrying themselves to a certain degree. rewatching them tonight and they could've had better attitudes towards the krumpers for sure. that aside, it's how much raw emotion and real-time events you get out of this. i've glanced over…
